free_text.Required prior knowledge: Basic undergraduate math and physics, some knowledge of digital signal processing helpful but not necessary
free_text.Content: 1.                    Introduction: Biological communication signals (acoustic, visual, haptic,..), their purpose, use and basic principles of their sensory perception in lower animals and in mammals. Arguments for human-like processing of cognitive signals. [br/]2.	Physiology of senses: Description of hearing and visual apparatus in animals and in humans, roles of individual components, neural firings, receptive fields, engineering implications.[br/]3.	Basic psychophysical concepts and techniques: Scales, types of perceptual experiments, just noticeable differences, detection theory, channel capacity of human perception. [br/]4.	Basic physiological measurement techniques: Threshold measurements, tuning curves, post-stimulus histogram, peri-stimulus histogram, reverse correlations (spike-triggered averages).[br/]5.	Similarities and differences between auditory and visual perception: Role of retina and of basi-lar membrane, lateral inhibition in vision and in hearing.[br/]6.	Psychophysics of sensory perception: Loudness and brightness, frequency selectivity, temporal resolution, power-law of perception, engineering implications.[br/]7.	Masking: Simultaneous masking, forward and backward masking in time, co-modulation masking release, engineering implications.[br/]8.	Perception of modulations: Modulation spectrum of important signals, sensitivity to modulations, engineering implications.[br/]9.	Multi-channel phenomena: Localization, release from masking, information fusion.[br/]10.	Engineering applications: Perceptual coders, auditory models in automatic speech recognition, emulation of animal communication for robotics applications.[br/]11.	Laboratory exercises: Perceptual demonstrations, simple perceptual experiments, MATLAB design of a simple auditory-like speech feature extraction.
free_text.Keywords: Biological communication signals, perception, psychophysics, physiology, signal processing
free_text.Learning outcomes: The goal of the course is to introduce engineering students to basic concepts of human processing of biological communication signals and to demonstrate advantages of emulation of the human-like signal processing by machine.
